bestBHT.bht: The seed in this scenario yielded no fruit because thorns existed in the ground, drawing away the soil's richness and moisture. These thorns effectively choked and compressed the seed, preventing it from taking root. This outcome is specific to Mark's account, indicating that it is not a condensed version. The prevailing thorns rendered the word ineffective and unsuccessful, failing to produce faith, grace, or good works. In essence, the word was unable to overcome and eliminate these hindrances, resulting in a fruitless outcome.

Henry Alford: In ver. 7 St. Mark adds and it yielded no fruit,
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This case is [like] ground not thoroughly cleaned... which, rising above the good seed, 'choke' or 'smother' it, excluding light and air, and drawing away the moisture and richness of the soil."
[The thorns] exist in [the soil] of what draws all the moisture and richness of the soil away to itself, and so starves the plant.
The evil here is neither a hard nor a shallow soil—there is softness enough, and depth enough; but it is the existence in it of what draws all the moisture and richness of the soil away to itself.
Marvin Vincent: Choked [συνεπνιξαν] . The preposition, sun = com (together), carries the idea of com - pression. It yielded no fruit. Added by Mark.
Philip Schaff: This Mark adds, showing that his account is not an abridgment.
The same result is of course implied in the other narrative.
Archibald T. Robertson: Choked (συνεπνιξαν). Πνιγω means to strangle, throttle.
Mark has the compounded form with συν-, squeezed together.
Yielded no fruit (καρπον ουκ εδωκαν). In Mark alone. Barren in results.
John Gill: The word did not take place so as to beat down, overcome, and root out these things, nor even to weaken, and keep under, and prevent the influence of them.
These got the ascendant of the word, and prevailed over it, and made it altogether useless and unsuccessful.
It was not the means of grace; faith did not come by it, nor any other grace; nor did it produce good works in the life and conversation.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 4:7, it is said that the seed yielded no fruit, and this is likened to ground where thorns exist and choke the good seed. These thorns draw away moisture and richness, starving the plant. The evil here is not a hard or shallow soil, but the existence of what draws all the soil's nutrients away. The compound form of choked implies compression and strangling. This result is unique to Mark's account and shows that it is not an abridgment, as it implies the same outcome as the other narratives. Overall, the word did not overcome or weaken these thorns, nor did it produce any desired results of faith, other graces, or good works.

In this passage, the  seed was choked by thorns that drew away the soil's richness and moisture. The compounded form of choked suggests compression and strangling. The result of no fruit is specific to the account in Mark, emphasizing that it is not an abridgment. The thorns prevailed over the word, rendering it useless and unproductive, failing to bring about faith and good works. This highlights the lack of impact and effectiveness of the word in overcoming these obstacles.

The seed in this scenario yielded no fruit because thorns existed in the ground, drawing away the soil's richness and moisture. These thorns effectively choked and compressed the seed, preventing it from taking root. This outcome is specific to Mark's account, indicating that it is not a condensed version. The prevailing thorns rendered the word ineffective and unsuccessful, failing to produce faith, grace, or good works. In essence, the word was unable to overcome and eliminate these hindrances, resulting in a fruitless outcome.

The seed failed to yield any fruit as thorns were present in the ground, depriving it of nourishment and stifling its growth. This choking effect, evidenced by the compound form of choked, compressed and strangled the seed. This outcome is unique to Mark's account, demonstrating its distinct nature. The prevailing thorns proved dominant over the word, resulting in its ineffectiveness and the absence of faith, grace, and good works. The Word was unable to overcome and eliminate these obstacles, leaving the result unfruitful.

In Mark's account, the seed failed to yield any fruit, choked by thorns that drew away the soil's richness and moisture. The compound form of choked indicates compression and strangling. This distinctive outcome highlights the effectiveness of Mark's narrative. The prevailing thorns rendered the word futile, unable to produce faith, grace, or good works. It could not overcome the hindrances, resulting in a fruitless outcome.
